data.title: Blue Denim (1959)
data.meta_description: Two naive high-school students must deal with the unexpected consequences after a night of passion.
data.text:
Hold up. Hold up.

You're telling me I just watched a film starring the kid from Shane, with a music score from the guy who composed Vertigo? And it happens to neither be a Western nor a Hitchock thriller? But a late 1950s teen drama?

Which is to say that none of those above things even factored into why I watched this film in the first place.

No, it was Marsha Hunt actually who was my gateway. For reference, she plays the mother of Brandon De Wilde (aka the kid from Shane).

Who is Marsha Hunt and why is she important to me? Hunt is somewhat forgotten these days. Woefully so. She wasn't super famous even in her day. The…

This was better than I expected, but I still struggled to stay fully engaged in the story and characters. For a film from the '50s, I thought it handled the subjects of teens, pregnancy, and abortion well considering the time period. The anti-abortion ending was expected but still kind of disappointing anyway.

I really liked how the film started and Brandon de Wilde and Carol Lynley were a great pairing. The fact that real teenagers played teen characters was great and they both captured the awkwardness and struggles with growing up very well. I just wish the movie hadn't actually been about pregnancy because the film went off the rails after that and never found its footing again since it…

BLUE DENIM really surprised me. The vast majority of films from the 1950’s that dealt with “teen problems” were ridiculously stilted at best or incredibly naïve and rigidly acted by performers who were much too old for their roles. Consequently, I wasn’t rushing to see BLUE DENIM, a film that dealt with teenage pregnancy.

When talking with a friend about it, I learned that the film was based on a play of the same name that was co-written by James Leo Herlihy. He wrote the novel that became MIDNIGHT COWBOY, and that film pulled no punches. So, I gave BLUE DENIM a try and found that it was quite good.

Released in 1959, the film is…
